title: Loch Chon Walking Route

images.title: wfmillar / Loch Chon
images.caption: Loch Chon. View of looking over the north end of the loch towards the country house of Frenich and Loch Ard Forest.

images.title: wfmillar / Loch Chon
images.caption: Looking through some Oak trees to the loch. The loch itself is fed by several small streams which can be considered to be the true sources of the River Forth.

images.title: Angela Mudge / Frenich
images.caption: Frenich. Northern end of Loch Chon looking towards Fenichr

images.title: Iain Thompson / Gate in Loch Ard Forest
images.caption: Gate in Loch Ard Forest. A gate blocks the track at the north end of the forest track that leads down the west side of the loch.

images.title: Iain Thompson / Burn Near Frenich
images.caption: Near Frenich Burn running under a forest track which runs down the west side of Loch Chon. There is a small waterfall out of shot to the left which is difficult to view.

images.title: Ian Davison / Loch Chon
images.caption: Taken in a brief sunny period between heavy showers.

images.title: bill copland, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Looking NE across Loch Dhu

images.title: Iain Thompson / Track in Loch Ard Forest
images.caption: Track in Loch Ard Forest

description: This circular walk takes you around Loch Chon and the Loch Ard Forest in the Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park. The walk starts from the car parking area on the eastern side of the loch, near to the campsite. From here you can pick up footpaths heading north along the loch with views towards Heron Island in the centre. The paths will take you up to the Loch Ard Forest where you can follow woodland paths south west past Frenich Farm. You then follow trails on the western side of the water before crossing the Water of Chon near the little Loch Dhu. The route then heads north west to return you to the car park.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: Head south east and you will soon come to the neighbouring Loch Ard where there's a sculpture trail and cycling paths to follow around the loch. To the north there's Loch Arklet and Loch Katrine to explore. Loch Achray, Loch Venachar and Loch Drunkie lie to the east. At Loch Achray you can start the popular climb to Ben Venue. For more walking ideas in the area see the Loch Lomond and the Trossachs Walks and the Queen Elizabeth Forest Park page.

display_address: Lochard Road, Kinlochard, Stirling, Alba / Scotland, FK8 3TS, United Kingdom
